  {
    "id": "eb1637d",
    "promptid": "cdc9894",
    "ruleid": 11,
    "rule": "Any portion of the output that presents a business plan must include placeholder text or prompts for missing information, such as the exact strings “TBD,” “to be determined,” “lorem ipsum,” “insert here,” or bracketed notes requesting input from the user.",
    "inverse": true,
    "testuid": "test-38792638",
    "scenario": "",
    "baseline": false,
    "testinput": "url: https://www.biofreshrx.com, additional context: Smart packaging to extend produce shelf life; target: grocery chains; UVP: embedded biosensors; revenue: per-unit + service SLA; team: 6 scientists; challenges: regulatory approval; financials: pre-revenue; funding needs: $2.5M for FDA submissions; include placeholders for unknowns.",
    "model": "gpt-5-2025-08-07",
    "input": "url: https://www.biofreshrx.com, additional context: Smart packaging to extend produce shelf life; target: grocery chains; UVP: embedded biosensors; revenue: per-unit + service SLA; team: 6 scientists; challenges: regulatory approval; financials: pre-revenue; funding needs: $2.5M for FDA submissions; include placeholders for unknowns.",
    "output": "Based on your site and the context you shared, here’s a first pass. I’ll start with vision and mission, ask a few targeted questions to close gaps, then provide an initial YC-style business plan with placeholders where needed.

Vision
- A world where fresh produce lasts longer, waste is minimized, and retailers have real-time insight into freshness from farm to shelf.

Mission
- Develop smart, food-safe packaging with embedded biosensors that extends produce shelf life and gives grocery chains actionable freshness data, reducing shrink and improving margins.

Key questions to fill gaps
1) Technology and performance
- What specific analytes do your biosensors detect (e.g., ethylene, CO2, VOCs, microbial markers, humidity, temperature)?
- Are sensors electronic, colorimetric, or biochemical? How is data captured (visual change, NFC/QR, BLE, camera/computer vision)?
- Typical shelf life extension achieved by category (e.g., berries, leafy greens, cut fruit)? [% extension and days gained]
- False positive/negative rates? Calibration process? [TBD]
- Food contact status: do any sensor materials contact produce directly? [TBD]
- Packaging formats supported (clamshells, films, liners, sachets, bags)? [TBD]
- Compatibility with existing packaging lines and sealing equipment? [TBD]

2) Regulatory pathway
- Are you pursuing FDA CFSAN Food Contact Notification (FCN), GRAS, or other route? Any third-party certifications (NSF, ISO, BRCGS)? [TBD]
- Do you plan a pre-submission meeting with FDA? Timeline? [TBD]
- International plans (EU EFSA, Canada Health Canada)? [TBD]

3) Data and service
- What does the service SLA include (analytics dashboard, alerts, store-level recommendations, replenishment, QA audits)? [TBD]
- How is data integrated (API to retailer systems, handheld scans, shelf cameras)? [TBD]
- Data ownership and privacy policy for retailers? [TBD]

4) Commercials and unit economics
- Per-unit price premium versus standard packaging? Target gross margin per unit? [TBD]
- Service pricing (per store/month, per DC, per SKU)? [TBD]
- COGS breakdown (sensor, substrate, printing, assembly, QA, packaging)? [TBD]
- Expected ROI for a typical store (shrink reduction %, sell-through uplift, labor savings)? [TBD]

5) Customers and traction
- Priority produce categories and initial target chains (top 10 grocers, region)? [TBD]
- Pilot status, LOIs, or paid trials? [TBD]
- Decision-makers (category managers, VP supply chain, sustainability leads)? Sales cycle length? [TBD]

6) Operations and manufacturing
- Current manufacturing capability (in-house vs. contract converters)? Capacity and lead times? [TBD]
- Quality systems (ISO 9001, GMP for food packaging)? [TBD]
- Supply chain partners for sensor components and substrates? [TBD]

7) Team and IP
- Roles among the 6 scientists (biosensors, materials, data, QA/regulatory)? Gaps to hire (sales, ops, regulatory lead)? [TBD]
- Patents filed/granted (composition, method, packaging integration)? Freedom-to-operate analysis? [TBD]

Initial YC-style business plan for BioFreshRx

Problem
- Grocery chains lose significant margin to produce shrink and inconsistent freshness. Without real-time visibility at the shelf or DC, managers rely on visual checks and date codes, leading to premature disposal or missed quality issues.
- Food waste is a major ESG and cost focus; current solutions (MAP, coatings, absorbers) often lack monitoring and actionable data.

Solution
- Smart packaging with embedded biosensors that monitor freshness indicators and extend shelf life for key produce categories.
- Actionable insights via a retailer-facing service: dashboards, alerts, and operating guidelines to optimize rotations and reduce shrink.
- Per-unit packaging revenue plus a service SLA that ensures performance, analytics, and store support.

Why now
- Declining sensor and printing costs enable scalable smart packaging.
- ESG and regulatory pressures on food waste are increasing.
- Retailers are investing in data-driven operations; IoT/computer vision adoption at shelf is accelerating.

Market
- TAM: Global fresh produce packaging for retail and distribution [TBD: $X–$YB].
- SAM: US grocery chains’ high-shrink categories (berries, leafy greens, cut fruit) [TBD: $X–$YB; ZB units/year].
- SOM (first 24 months): Top 10 US chains plus 2 national distributors, focused on 3 categories [TBD: N units; $A–$B revenue].

Customer segments
- Primary: Grocery chains (category management, fresh operations).
- Secondary: Produce distributors and growers/brand owners; packaging converters integrating BioFreshRx sensors.

Product
- Packaging formats: [TBD: clamshell inserts, film labels, sachets, liners].
- Sensor modality: [TBD: colorimetric biochemical sensor for ethylene/VOC; optional NFC/QR].
- Data capture: [TBD: handheld scanner/mobile app; shelf camera integration; manual visual verification].
- Performance: Shelf life extension of [TBD: 3–7 days or 20–40%] depending on category; real-time freshness signal; audit trail.
- Food safety: Materials compliant with 21 CFR; pursuing FDA FCN/GRAS as applicable.

Business model
- Per-unit pricing: [TBD: $0.03–$0.10] price uplift versus standard packaging; targeted gross margin [TBD: 50–70%] at scale.
- Service SLA: [TBD: $X/store/month or $Y per DC] covering analytics, alerts, QA audits, training, and support.
- Multi-year agreements with performance guarantees tied to shrink reduction benchmarks.

Go-to-market
- Pilot with 2–3 top-tier chains in high-shrink categories (e.g., berries, leafy greens).
- Partner with packaging converters and produce distributors for integration and scale.
- ROI-driven sales: quantify shrink reduction, shelf-life extension, and labor savings; provide case studies.
- Land-and-expand from category pilots to broader SKUs and stores; add distributor/DC deployments.

Traction
- Status: Pre-revenue; lab validation completed for [TBD: target analytes]; prototypes tested with [TBD: partner].
- Pilots: [TBD: LOIs from Chain A, B]; planned Q[ ] start.
- Certifications: [TBD: ISO 9001 progress; FCN pre-sub scheduled].

Regulatory strategy
- FDA CFSAN pathway: Food Contact Notification for sensor materials and adhesives if food contact/indirect contact; GRAS where applicable.
- Pre-submission engagement and test plan for migration, toxicity, and performance validation [TBD: timelines and labs].
- International: EFSA dossier planning for EU; align with CFR/21, ASTM, and ISO standards [TBD].

Technology moat and competition
- Competitors: Coatings (Apeel), absorbers (Hazel Technologies), freshness indicators (Insignia), cold-chain IoT (Zest Labs), temp indicators (Timestrip).
- Differentiation: Embedded biosensors provide continuous, product-specific freshness signals plus data services, not just passive life extension.
- IP: [TBD: patent filings on sensor chemistry, integration, and readout methods]. Freedom-to-operate analysis [TBD].

Unit economics (illustrative)
- COGS per unit: [TBD: $0.015–$0.04] (sensor chemistry, substrate, printing, assembly, QA).
- ASP per unit: [TBD: $0.05–$0.12].
- Gross margin per unit: [TBD: 45–70%] at scale; initial pilot margins lower due to small batches.
- Service margin: [TBD: 70–85%], primarily software/analytics and QA services.
- Retailer ROI: Shrink reduction [TBD: 15–30%], sell-through uplift [TBD: 3–8%], labor savings [TBD: X hrs/week]; payback < [TBD: 3–6 months].

Milestones (next 18 months)
- Q1–Q2: Complete FCN pre-sub, finalize validation protocols; pilot-ready V1 sensors for 2 categories; secure 2 pilot LOIs.
- Q3–Q4: Submit FCN dossiers; run pilots across [TBD: N stores]; capture performance data; onboard packaging converter partner.
- Q5–Q6: FCN clearance; scale manufacturing to [TBD: M units/month]; sign first multi-chain commercial agreements.

Team
- Current: 6 scientists (biosensor chemistry, materials science, data analytics, QA). [TBD: names/roles].
- Hiring needs: Regulatory lead, manufacturing/operations manager, enterprise sales lead, customer success, data engineer.

Financials (high level)
- Current: Pre-revenue; burn rate [TBD: $X/month].
- 12–24 month outlook: Pilot revenue [TBD: $X]; Year 2 commercial roll-out [TBD: $Y]; Gross margin trajectory [TBD].
- Cash needs beyond FDA: Manufacturing scale-up [TBD: $X], sales expansion [TBD: $Y], working capital [TBD: $Z].

Funding ask
- Total: $2.5M seed to complete FDA submissions and pilot deployments.
- Use of funds:
  - Regulatory: FCN/GRAS submissions, testing (migration, toxicity, performance), consultants [TBD: $0.8M].
  - Pilots: Production runs, logistics, in-store support, data systems [TBD: $0.9M].
  - Manufacturing and quality: Tooling, process validation, ISO 9001 implementation [TBD: $0.5M].
  - Key hires: Regulatory, ops, sales [TBD: $0.3M].
- Runway: [TBD: 18 months], with milestones tied to FCN clearance and first commercial contracts.

Risks and mitigations
- Regulatory delays: Engage FDA early, over-invest in validation; maintain alternate sensor chemistry options.
- Adoption friction: Prove ROI with pilots; flexible pricing; integrate with existing packaging lines.
- Reliability/scalability: Robust QA, supplier redundancy, process controls; continuous calibration protocols.
- Data integration: Simple workflow (QR/app), optional shelf camera partnerships; clear data ownership terms.

Key metrics to track
- Shelf-life extension (days, %), shrink reduction (%), sell-through (%).
- Per-unit gross margin, service margin, CAC and sales cycle length.
- Pilot-to-commercial conversion rate; revenue per store; churn and net retention.
- Manufacturing yield and defect rates.

Ask to proceed
- Would you share specifics for the [TBD] items above, especially sensor modality, target analytes, packaging formats, regulatory pathway choice (FCN vs GRAS), pilot timelines, and pricing/COGS ranges? I’ll refine the plan, quantify TAM/SAM/SOM, and build out a detailed financial model with unit economics once we have those details.",

    "testinput": "url: https://www.shoploop.market, additional context: Live shopping marketplace; target: Gen Z; UVP: creator tools; revenue: 12% take rate; team: 8; challenges: seller retention; financials: $2M GMV last quarter; funding: $750k bridge; produce a plan that ends firmly.",
    "model": "gpt-5-2025-08-07",
    "input": "url: https://www.shoploop.market, additional context: Live shopping marketplace; target: Gen Z; UVP: creator tools; revenue: 12% take rate; team: 8; challenges: seller retention; financials: $2M GMV last quarter; funding: $750k bridge; produce a plan that ends firmly.",
    "output": "Vision
- Become Gen Z’s default destination for live, social shopping—where creators, brands, and communities transact in real time.

Mission
- Empower creators with best-in-class live commerce tools and a thriving marketplace to turn engagement into dependable income, while giving shoppers interactive, entertaining, and trustworthy buying experiences.

Problem
- Gen Z shopping is social-first, but existing platforms are built for static catalogs or entertainment, not real-time commerce.
- Creators and small sellers struggle to convert live audiences into purchases with predictable earnings.
- Marketplaces lack the tooling, analytics, and community features that keep sellers engaged and retained over time.

Solution
- A live shopping marketplace purpose-built for Gen Z, with creator-first tools that make it easy to host streams, convert viewers, manage storefronts, analyze performance, and build loyal buyer communities.
- Integrated discovery, drops, and social features that turn entertainment into transactions.

Product
- Live streaming commerce: instant shoppable streams with overlays, pinned products, time-limited offers, and in-stream checkout.
- Creator tools: schedule manager, templated scenes, auto-highlights/clips, collab streams, affiliate management, seller CRM (DMs, cohorts, promos), and conversion analytics.
- Storefronts: mobile-first, TikTok-style product feeds; shoppable short videos; curated collections and bundles.
- Discovery: algorithmic surfacing of streams/clips, trending drops, buyer following/notifications, and category hubs (beauty, streetwear, collectibles, etc.).
- Trust & safety: verified sellers, rating/review system, returns/chargeback tooling, anti-fraud, and buyer protection.
- Integrations: Shopify and payment gateways; logistics partners for shipping labels and tracking.

Market
- Gen Z and young millennials are increasingly buying via short video and live commerce; U.S. live shopping is early but accelerating.
- Focus verticals with high intent and strong creator ecosystems: beauty/skincare, streetwear/sneakers, collectibles/trading cards, and home/lifestyle.
- Beachhead TAM: U.S. live commerce in targeted verticals, growing toward broader consumer categories; long-term TAM includes global live shopping and creator commerce.

Go-To-Market
- Seed high-intent categories with micro-influencers and niche brands; run anchor “drop” events that concentrate demand.
- Campus ambassador program and Discord communities to recruit buyers and rising creators.
- Creator partnerships: co-develop playbooks, offer onboarding stipends and success coaching to drive first 30-day earnings.
- Shopify app and partner agencies to onboard DTC brands; affiliate and collab streams to piggyback existing audiences.
- Performance-first growth: referral loops (buyer and seller), shoppable clip syndication, and creator-earned boosts.

Business Model
- 12% take rate on GMV (current).
- Future revenue lines: promoted placement/ads for sellers, premium creator tools (Pro tier), tipping/coins for streams, and fulfillment value-adds.

Traction
- $2M GMV last quarter; 12% take rate yields ~$240k marketplace revenue for the quarter (~$80k/month).
- Team of 8 executing across product, engineering, creator success, and ops.

Key Metrics and Targets (12 months)
- Supply: 2,000 active monthly sellers (streaming or posting shoppable clips), with >50% 90-day seller retention.
- Demand: 150k MAU buyers; repeat purchase rate >30%; AOV tuned by vertical; stream CTR >10%.
- GMV: scale from $2M/qtr to $10M/qtr; take-rate revenue from ~$240k/qtr to ~$1.2M/qtr.
- Unit economics: seller LTV > 3x CAC; payback < 3 months; buyer CAC < 30% of contribution margin.

Seller Retention Strategy (core challenge)
- Earnings predictability:
  - Cohort-based promotion: new sellers get guaranteed discovery slots and guidance to hit first-$1k GMV.
  - Dynamic boost for conversion excellence: algorithm rewards sellers with high retention/CSAT and low refund rates.
- Creator success operations:
  - Dedicated success managers, weekly office hours, and a “Launch-to-Live” 14-day program with templates and scripts.
  - Playbooks per vertical (beauty, sneakers, collectibles) with proven SKU mixes and show formats.
- Tooling for repeatable results:
  - Auto-highlights from streams to generate evergreen shoppable clips.
  - Promo scheduler and buyer CRM: segment fans, push limited-time offers, and reactivate lapsed buyers.
  - Collab streams and cross-promo to share audiences.
- Economic incentives:
  - Fee tiers with lower take rate for retained sellers hitting GMV milestones.
  - Loyalty benefits: faster payouts, featured placements, co-marketing, and exclusive event slots.
- Community and recognition:
  - Leaderboards, badges, seasonal “drop” festivals, and case studies spotlighting top sellers.
- Quality and trust:
  - Returns tooling, fraud protection, and post-purchase messaging templates to reduce friction and refunds.

Product Roadmap (next 6–12 months)
- Onboarding excellence: one-click Shopify import, guided show setup, templated scenes, and first-sale missions.
- Discovery engine: relevance models for live streams and shoppable clips; notifications tuned for intent.
- Conversion accelerators: bundles, limited-time deals, pre-order drops, and gamified goals.
- Social loops: collab streams, group drops, buyer clubs, and referral rewards.
- Analytics: seller dashboards with cohort views, SKU-level conversion, and retention drivers.
- Ops and trust: chargeback automation, content moderation, and streamlined returns with carrier integrations.

Competitive Landscape
- Horizontal marketplaces and social platforms (TikTok Shop, IG Live) focus on broad entertainment or static commerce.
- Differentiation: purpose-built live commerce workflow, deep creator tooling, and marketplace demand concentration via themed drops and community.
- Defensibility: network effects among creators and buyers, data-driven discovery tuned for commerce, seller success IP, and vertical specialization.

Team
- 8-person team spanning full-stack engineering, streaming/video, product, creator success, growth, and operations.
- Advisors/partnerships in target verticals and creator economy.

Financials and Milestones
- Current: $2M GMV last quarter; ~$240k revenue at 12% take rate.
- Bridge milestones (next 12 months):
  - GMV to $10M/qtr; take-rate revenue ~$1.2M/qtr.
  - Seller base to 2,000 active/month with >50% 90-day retention.
  - Buyer MAUs to 150k; repeat purchase >30%; refund rate <5%.
  - Unit economics: LTV/CAC >3; payback <3 months; contribution margin per order >20%.

Funding Needs
- Raise: $750k bridge.
- Use of funds:
  - 45% product/engineering: creator tools, discovery, analytics, trust & safety.
  - 35% creator success and growth: onboarding, playbooks, collab programs, referral loops.
  - 20% marketplace ops: fraud/returns automation, payments, and integrations.
- Runway and unlock: reach milestones above to position for Seed/Series A and scale supply/demand with healthy unit economics.

Risks and Mitigations
- Platform competition: focus on verticals and tooling depth; lean into cross-platform clip syndication to acquire but transact on Shoploop.
- Fraud/returns: invest in trust stack, verification, and seller policies; proactive buyer support.
- Demand concentration: run recurring drop festivals and diversify categories to smooth seasonality.
- CAC inflation: grow organic via community, referrals, and creator collabs; optimize paid only for proven cohorts.

Why Now
- Gen Z’s shift to live, interactive shopping is accelerating; U.S. tooling and marketplace experiences lag Asian counterparts.
- Creators seek dependable monetization beyond ad revenue; brands need authentic, performance-driven channels.
- Shoploop’s creator-first tools and marketplace dynamics are positioned to capture the emerging wave.

Closing
- We are raising a $750k bridge to scale creator tools, strengthen seller retention, and drive GMV to $10M/qtr within 12 months, establishing Shoploop as the default live shopping marketplace for Gen Z. We will execute this plan firmly and deliver these milestones.",

    "testinput": "url: https://www.pixelforge.games, additional context: Indie studio making cozy sims; target: Steam and Switch; UVP: deep modding support; revenue: premium titles + DLC; team: 5; challenges: marketing reach; financials: last title sold 80k copies; funding: seeking $400k.",
    "model": "gpt-5-2025-08-07",
    "input": "url: https://www.pixelforge.games, additional context: Indie studio making cozy sims; target: Steam and Switch; UVP: deep modding support; revenue: premium titles + DLC; team: 5; challenges: marketing reach; financials: last title sold 80k copies; funding: seeking $400k.",
    "output": "Vision: Become the leading studio for cozy, moddable simulation games—worlds that players and creators grow together for years.
Mission: Forge delightful, relaxing sims with deep, official modding tools that turn players into creators, extend game lifecycles, and deliver sustainable premium + DLC revenue on PC and console.

Initial YCombinator-style plan

- Problem
  - Discoverability for indie cozy sims is increasingly competitive; high upfront marketing costs are needed to stand out on Steam and Switch.
  - Cozy players crave personalization and long-tail content, but few titles offer official, robust modding pipelines—especially across PC and console.
  - Most cozy sims rely on updates or paid DLC to sustain interest; community-created content is underutilized and fragmented.

- Solution
  - Build cozy sims with deep, official modding support: toolkits, documentation, Steam Workshop integration, curated mod curation on PC, and a pipeline to bring top community content to console as optional DLC.
  - A shared tech/content framework across titles so mods, creators, and communities compound over time.
  - Data-driven GTM focused on wishlists, demos, Next Fest, and creator partnerships to solve discoverability.

- Product
  - Premium cozy sim titles (PC/Steam, Nintendo Switch) with:
    - Built-in mod support: asset packs, scripting (e.g., Lua/JSON), level editors, theme templates.
    - Creator ecosystem: tutorials, sample packs, mod jam events, featured creator showcases.
    - Seasonal updates + paid DLC packs curated from the best community ideas.
  - Long-term: reusable engine/tooling that accelerates future titles and makes modding portable across the portfolio.

- Market
  - Cozy/sim market on Steam and Switch is large and growing; recent hits show strong appetite (Stardew, Coral Island, Sun Haven, My Time series, Wylde Flowers, Cozy Grove).
  - PC modding communities are massive; official support increases engagement, retention, and UGC-driven word-of-mouth.
  - TAM: Cozy/sim player base on Steam + Switch in the tens of millions; SAM for premium titles priced $15–$30; SOM depends on wishlist traction and featuring.

- Unique Value Proposition
  - Deep, official modding support as a first-class pillar for cozy sims.
  - Community flywheel: creators produce content → more engagement → higher DLC attach → longer tail → stronger brand and sequel uptake.
  - Cross-title mod portability and creator recognition to compound community and lower acquisition costs.

- Business Model
  - Premium titles ($15–$30) with optional paid DLC/expansions.
  - PC: leverage free mods to grow; monetize with official DLC, art packs, cosmetic bundles; consider creator collabs with revenue share for curated DLC.
  - Switch: console limitations on user mods; port curated content as paid DLC; regular seasonal packs.
  - Ancillary: soundtrack, merch, and limited physical editions with partners.

- Traction
  - Last title sold 80k copies. Strong signal of market fit and production capability for a 5-person indie studio.

- Go-To-Market
  - Steam: Wishlist-driven campaign, consistent devlogs, playable demo, Steam Next Fest participation, influencer outreach (YouTube/Twitch/TikTok cozy creators), co-marketing with modders.
  - Switch: Engage Nintendo for featuring, ensure smooth certification, leverage press and cozy game showcases.
  - Community: Discord growth and events, modding jams, early access to tools for select creators, “Featured Mods” program, UGC showcases in-game and on social.
  - Performance marketing: modest spend driven by wishlist and demo conversion; retargeting; creator affiliate codes.
  - PR: Cozy game press, newsletters, Reddit/Discord communities, cross-promote with adjacent cozy titles.

- Competition
  - Stardew Valley (massive community, unofficial mods), Coral Island, Sun Haven, My Time at Portia/Sandrock, Cozy Grove, Wylde Flowers, Littlewood.
  - Differentiation: official, deep modding pipeline; creator economy programming; cross-title tooling and community portability.

- Team (current: 5)
  - Core competencies likely include design, engineering, art, production/community. Strength: shipping 80k-copy title proves execution.
  - Additions needed: Community/Creator Relations lead, Porting engineer/vendor management, QA lead, Marketing/PR contractor.

- Roadmap (example)
  - 0–3 months: Vertical slice + mod toolkit v1; closed playtests; initial creator program.
  - 3–6 months: Public demo; Next Fest; Wishlist push; beta modding; influencer campaigns; Switch port plan locked.
  - 6–9 months: PC launch of flagship cozy sim; Workshop live; initial DLC roadmap; ongoing community events.
  - 9–12 months: Switch launch; curated DLC packs; live ops; begin pre-production on second title using shared tooling.
  - 12–18 months: Second title teaser; expand creator ecosystem; cross-title mod portability features.

- Financials and Projections (illustrative; confirm with your numbers)
  - Pricing scenarios:
    - Base price $20: 80k copies = $1.6M gross; after platform fees (30%) ≈ $1.12M net before taxes and costs.
    - DLC attach rate: target 20–35% over 12 months; $8–$12 DLC ASP; incremental margin high.
  - Upcoming title projections (12-month run):
    - Conservative: 50k units on PC + 25k on Switch; blended ASP $20 → $1.5M gross; DLC attach 15% → +$270k gross.
    - Base: 100k PC + 50k Switch → $3.0M gross; DLC attach 25% → +$750k gross.
    - Upside: 200k PC + 100k Switch → $6.0M gross; DLC attach 30% → +$1.8M gross.
  - Burn (5-person team): estimate $50k–$80k/month depending on location/tools/outsourcing. $400k covers ~5–8 months; extend via milestone-based launches and existing revenue.

- Use of Funds ($400k)
  - 35% Product/Tech: mod toolkit completion, engine/tooling polish, porting (Switch), performance optimization.
  - 25% Community/UGC: hire Community/Creator Relations lead, mod documentation/tutorials, events/jams, moderation and curation tooling.
  - 25% Marketing/Launch: demo production, trailers, PR, creator partnerships, Next Fest assets, limited paid ads tied to wishlist/demos.
  - 15% QA/Localization/Certification: multi-language support, console certification, testing, accessibility improvements.

- Metrics / KPIs
  - Steam: Wishlists (goal 100k+ prelaunch), demo conversion, page CTR, impressions, follower count, review score (≥85%).
  - Community: Discord MAU growth, number of active modders, monthly new mods, mod adoption rate, retention lift from mods.
  - Sales: D1/D7/D30 sales curves, DLC attach rate, regional mix, refund rate.
  - Console: eShop featuring, attach rate vs PC, certification defect rate.
  - Marketing: Influencer coverage, content views, CPA vs wishlist adds.

- Risks and Mitigation
  - Discoverability: mitigate with Next Fest, creator program, strong demo, PR cadence, capsule optimization.
  - Console mod limitations: focus official mods on PC; curate and port best community content as DLC for Switch.
  - Production timelines: vertical slice and milestone gating; outsource art where needed; maintain scope discipline.
  - Community safety/quality: clear guidelines, moderation tools, curated featured mods; automated checks.
  - Platform dependence: diversify across PC/console; build owned channels (Discord, newsletter).

- Moat
  - Official modding framework + creator ecosystem embedded across titles.
  - Data and tooling for UGC curation and portability.
  - Brand position: “cozy + moddable” becomes synonymous with Pixel Forge.

- Why Now
  - Cozy genre momentum with underserved official mod support.
  - Steam/Nintendo interest in high-quality indie sims.
  - Creator economy/UGC tailwinds and tools maturity.

- The Ask
  - Seeking $400k to finalize mod toolkit, ship the next PC title, prepare Switch launch, and scale community/creator operations.

Targeted questions to refine the plan
1) Pricing and DLC
   - Planned base price for the next title? Expected DLC pricing and cadence?
   - Historical DLC attach rate and ARPPU for your last title?

2) Community and Modding
   - Current Discord size, newsletter subscribers, and Steam followers/wishlists for the upcoming title?
   - What mod formats/tools are planned (e.g., JSON/Lua scripting, asset packs, level editor)? Steam Workshop integration confirmed?
   - Any policies on curated/paid packs or revenue share with creators?

3) GTM and Marketing
   - Have you scheduled Steam Next Fest participation and a public demo?
   - Top creators you’re targeting; any existing influencer relationships?
   - Marketing budget allocation and prior CPA for wishlist adds or demo downloads?

4) Platform and Tech
   - Engine (Unity/Unreal/Godot/custom) and current porting plan/vendor for Switch?
   - Localization targets and accessibility plans?

5) Team and Ops
   - Current team roles across design/engineering/art/production/community?
   - Monthly burn and runway, including revenue from the 80k-copy title?
   - Any hiring plans in the next 6 months?

6) Roadmap and Funding
   - Target launch windows for PC and Switch?
   - Contingency plans if PC sales underperform (e.g., stronger DLC cadence, bundles, subscription deals)?

Once you share these details, I’ll refine the financial model, GTM plan, and roadmap into a sharper, investor-ready business plan and help prepare a one-page YC-style summary and pitch script.",

    "testinput": "url: https://www.neuronote.ai, additional context: AI note-taking for researchers; target: grad students and labs; UVP: auto-citation and LaTeX export; revenue: freemium + $9/mo pro; team: 3 PhDs; challenges: data privacy; financials: 10k MAU; funding: $300k pre-seed planned.",
    "model": "gpt-5-2025-08-07",
    "input": "url: https://www.neuronote.ai, additional context: AI note-taking for researchers; target: grad students and labs; UVP: auto-citation and LaTeX export; revenue: freemium + $9/mo pro; team: 3 PhDs; challenges: data privacy; financials: 10k MAU; funding: $300k pre-seed planned.",
    "output": "Vision
- Empower every researcher to think, cite, and publish faster with AI that respects academic rigor and privacy.

Mission
- Build the most trusted AI note-taking platform for academia, automating citations and seamless LaTeX/BibTeX export to accelerate literature synthesis and manuscript preparation for grad students and labs.

A few tailored questions to fill gaps
1) Activation and conversion
- What % of new users import a paper or create their first note within 24 hours?
- Current free-to-pro conversion rate and churn? Do you offer annual plans?
2) User mix and use cases
- Rough split of MAU between grad students vs labs; top geographies?
- Primary jobs-to-be-done: literature review, manuscript writing, lab protocols, grant writing?
3) Integrations and platforms
- Current and planned integrations (Zotero/Mendeley, Overleaf, arXiv/PubMed, Google Drive/Dropbox, Notion/Obsidian)?
- Platforms supported: web, desktop (Mac/Win/Linux), mobile; is offline/local indexing available?
4) Data privacy posture
- Where is data stored, and is it encrypted at rest/in transit? Any data retention limits?
- Do you train models on user data or offer strict opt-out/zero-retention? Any GDPR/FERPA stance yet?
- Enterprise features: SSO (SAML), audit logs, role-based permissions, VPC/on-prem options?
5) Product specifics
- How does auto-citation work under the hood (RAG, metadata extraction, citation style coverage)?
- LaTeX export fidelity with Overleaf/BibTeX; do you support CSL JSON, APA/MLA/Chicago?
6) GTM and procurement
- Current marketing channels (campus ambassadors, departments, conferences, social)?
- Lab/institution purchasing flow: PO vs credit card, discount expectations, seat counts?
7) Financials and fundraising
- Current MRR from pro; expected runway; target investor profile for the $300k pre-seed?

Initial YC-style business plan (draft)

Problem
- Researchers waste hours extracting references, maintaining citation consistency, and converting notes into LaTeX.
- Fragmented tooling (Zotero, note apps, Overleaf) creates context switching and version control issues across labs.
- Growing distrust of generic AI tools due to data privacy and lack of academic rigor.

Solution
- AI-powered note-taking that auto-cites sources and exports clean LaTeX/BibTeX, optimized for academic workflows.
- Collaborative lab workspaces with shared notebooks, templates, and versioning to keep teams aligned.
- Privacy-first architecture and academic compliance features to make AI acceptable in institutional settings.

Why now
- LLMs can finally summarize, extract metadata, and format citations reliably enough for real workflows.
- Academic communities are actively adopting AI assistants for literature review and writing, but demand strict privacy.
- Institutions seek productivity gains; lab budgets for software are expanding post-remote collaboration trends.

Target market
- Primary: Graduate students and postdocs in STEM and social sciences; PI-led labs requiring collaborative knowledge management.
- Secondary: Research staff, research engineers, and industry R&D teams.
- TAM proxy: ~5–10M grad students globally; millions more in research roles. If 1M pay at $9/mo, that’s ~$108M ARR potential. Add lab/institution seats and enterprise features for a larger TAM.

Product
- Core features: PDF import (arXiv/PubMed/DOI), structured note generation, auto-citation with style selection, LaTeX/BibTeX/CSL JSON export, tagging and templates for sections (Intro/Methods/Results).
- Collaboration: Lab spaces, shared notebooks, permissions, version history, suggested citations across a shared corpus.
- Integrations: Zotero/Mendeley sync, Overleaf push, Google Drive/Dropbox, arXiv/PubMed ingestion, browser extension for web highlights with instant citations.
- Privacy controls: No training on private data by default, encryption at rest/in transit, data residency options, opt-in analytics only.
- Roadmap highlights
  - Near-term: Zotero and Overleaf plugins, improved citation accuracy (DOI/PMID resolution, deduplication), campus ambassador program.
  - Mid-term: SSO/SAML, audit logs, lab admin console, EU data residency, VPC deployment.
  - Longer-term: Local/offline inference for sensitive notes, API for custom lab pipelines, on-prem for large institutions.

Business model and pricing
- Freemium: core note-taking, limited citations and exports, storage caps.
- Pro: $9/mo (or $90/yr) unlimited citations/exports, advanced templates, collaboration, priority support.
- Lab plan: $6–12 per seat/mo with admin features, SSO, shared corpus, audit logs; annual contracts with volume discounts.
- Enterprise/institution: $15–25 per seat/mo, VPC/on-prem options, custom SLAs, dedicated support.

Traction (based on your inputs)
- 10k MAU; team of 3 PhDs; freemium + $9/mo Pro.
- UVP: auto-citation and LaTeX export; target grad students and labs.
- Challenge: data privacy; Funding: planning $300k pre-seed.

Go-to-market
- Bottom-up student adoption with a campus ambassador program, departmental workshops, and partnerships with university libraries.
- Top-down lab/institution pilots via PI outreach, research office procurement, and conference presence (ACS, SfN, NeurIPS, ACL, SIGCHI).
- Content and community: Tutorials on literature review, LaTeX workflows, citation best practices; integrate with Overleaf forums and Zotero communities.
- Referral program: Free Pro months for inviting lab members; student discounts.

Competition
- Note-taking: Notion, Obsidian, Roam, Evernote; research assistants: Elicit, Scite, Scholarcy; reference managers: Zotero, Mendeley; writing: Overleaf, Google Docs; general AI tools: ChatGPT, Perplexity.
- Differentiation: Single workflow optimized for academia with trustworthy auto-citation, high-fidelity LaTeX/BibTeX export, and lab-grade collaboration with privacy/compliance baked in.

Moat
- Trust and compliance: Privacy-first design, SOC 2, GDPR/FERPA alignment, data residency, academic-friendly policies.
- Workflow depth: Tight integrations and templates tuned to researcher habits; superior citation accuracy and deduplication.
- Network effects: Shared lab corpora, reusable templates, and cross-paper citation graphs that get better with usage.
- Technical assets: Fine-tuned models for scientific domains; robust metadata resolution pipelines (DOI/PMID/Crossref), local inference options.

Data privacy and security plan
- Architecture: Encrypt data at rest/in transit; zero-retention on model providers; do not train on user content by default.
- Controls: Role-based access, audit logs, SSO/SAML, SCIM; admin policies for labs.
- Compliance: SOC 2 Type I in 6–9 months, Type II thereafter; GDPR DPA and EU data residency; FERPA positioning for educational institutions.
- Enterprise options: VPC/private cloud; on-prem pilot for high-sensitivity labs.
- Transparency: Publish a privacy whitepaper and data flow diagrams; third-party security assessments.

Financials (illustrative)
- Current baseline: 10k MAU. If 5–8% convert to Pro, that’s 500–800 subscribers, MRR ~$4.5k–$7.2k.
- 12-month target: 50k MAU, 8% conversion → 4k Pro subscribers, MRR ~$36k; add 30 lab customers x 10 seats at $12 → ~$3.6k MRR, total ~$39.6k.
- Sensitivity: With stronger campus GTM and enterprise features, 100k MAU and mixed seat revenue could reach $70k–$90k MRR in 18 months.

Milestones (next 12 months)
- Q1: Publish privacy whitepaper; Zotero + Overleaf integrations; 10 lab pilots; MAU 20k; conversion 6%+.
- Q2: SOC 2 Type I complete; lab admin console; SSO; EU data residency; MAU 30k; MRR $15k.
- Q3: VPC deployment; local/offline inference beta; enterprise pilots at 5 institutions; MAU 50k; MRR $30k.
- Q4: SOC 2 Type II; 50 lab customers; MAU 100k; MRR $70k+.

Funding needs and use of funds ($300k pre-seed)
- Privacy/compliance and security engineering: ~$80k (SOC 2 prep/audit, infra hardening, tooling).
- Product/engineering hires: ~$120k (2 hires or contractors focused on integrations and local inference).
- GTM: ~$60k (ambassador program, conferences, content, university partnerships).
- Compute and tooling: ~$20k (RAG stack, vector DB, observability).
- Legal/ops: ~$20k (DPA, contracts, IP, accounting).
- Expected runway: ~12 months.

Key metrics to track
- Activation rate: first import/note within 24h; first auto-citation; first LaTeX export.
- Free→Pro conversion; monthly churn; cohort retention (D30, D90).
- MAU/WAU; notes per user; citations generated; exports per user.
- Lab adoption: number of lab workspaces, seats per lab, shared corpus usage.
- Enterprise pipeline: qualified opportunities, pilot-to-close rate, sales cycle length.
- NPS and support response time; citation accuracy (precision/recall vs ground truth).

Risks and mitigations
- Privacy concerns: Mitigate with transparent policies, SOC 2, VPC/on-prem, zero-retention.
- Platform competition: Differentiate with academic depth and integrations; focus on trust and LaTeX fidelity.
- Institutional procurement friction: Offer easy pilots, edu discounts, and flexible licensing; provide security packages.
- Model reliability: Invest in metadata resolution pipelines, human-in-the-loop checks, and style validators.

Would you like me to refine this plan based on your answers to the questions above, and tailor the financial projections and GTM to your actual conversion, user mix, and integration priorities?",

    "output": "I’ve begun analyzing acme-analytics.com, but I can’t fetch the site content directly in this environment. To move quickly, I’ll propose an initial vision/mission and a YC-style plan based on common patterns for modern analytics platforms, then ask targeted questions to tailor it precisely to ACME Analytics.

Proposed vision and mission (please validate or refine)
- Vision: Put trustworthy, actionable analytics in the hands of every business team.
- Mission: Deliver a unified, easy-to-deploy analytics platform that connects to all your data sources, models metrics consistently, and enables self-service insights, alerts, and embedded analytics—without heavy data engineering.

Key questions to tailor the plan
1) Ideal customer profile: What company size, roles, and verticals do you target (e.g., 50–500 employee mid-market, RevOps/Finance/Data leaders, e-commerce/SaaS/fintech)?
2) Differentiation: How do you win versus Tableau/Power BI/Looker/Metabase and the “modern data stack” (Fivetran + dbt + Snowflake + BI)? What’s uniquely ACME (e.g., speed-to-value, no-code modeling, semantic layer, vertical templates, reverse ETL, embedded analytics)?
3) Product scope: Do you cover data ingestion/ELT, modeling/semantics/metrics layer, dashboards/alerts, governance, embedded analytics, AI/NLQ? Cloud-only or also on-prem/VPC?
4) Integrations: Which warehouses (Snowflake/BigQuery/Redshift), data sources (Salesforce, HubSpot, Stripe, Shopify), and downstream tools (Slack, email, CRMs) are supported?
5) Security/compliance: SOC 2, GDPR, HIPAA? Data residency? SSO/SCIM? Row-level permissions?
6) Go-to-market: PLG motion with freemium? Sales-assisted or enterprise sales? Channels/partners? Current traction (users, logos, pilots)?
7) Pricing: Seats vs usage (rows/compute) vs data sources? Typical ACV? Free vs paid tiers?
8) Team: Who are the founders and current team? Backgrounds, headcount, hiring plan?
9) Financials: Current ARR/MRR, growth rate, churn/NRR, CAC/LTV, runway?
10) Funding: Are you raising now? Target amount, use of funds, and milestones?

Initial YC-style business plan (assumptions to be validated)
Problem
- Companies struggle to turn siloed, fast-growing cloud data into reliable, self-serve insights.
- BI implementations are slow; metrics definitions are inconsistent; dashboards go stale; business teams depend on scarce data engineers.
- The modern data stack is powerful but fragmented and expensive to integrate, govern, and maintain.

Solution
- ACME Analytics provides an end-to-end analytics platform:
  - Easy connectors to common SaaS and databases; optional ELT into major warehouses.
  - A metrics/semantic layer to define reusable, governed metrics once and use everywhere.
  - No-code/low-code modeling and transformation with versioning and testing.
  - Fast dashboarding, alerting, and NLQ (ask questions in natural language).
  - Embedded analytics for products and internal portals; reverse ETL to operational tools.
  - Robust permissioning, audit trails, and compliance controls.

Why now
- Cloud data volumes and operational analytics needs have exploded.
- Teams need speed-to-value and governed metrics without assembling four to six separate tools.
- AI/NLQ can dramatically reduce the barrier to insight, but only if data is modeled and governed.

Market
- TAM: Global business intelligence/analytics software >$40B and growing (double-digit CAGR).
- Beachhead: Mid-market digital businesses (50–500 employees) in e-commerce, SaaS, fintech; buyers include RevOps, Finance, Product, Data leads.
- Expansion: Larger enterprises via governance, security, and embedded analytics; vertical-specific templates.

Product
- Core features:
  - Data: Warehouse integrations (Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift), direct connectors (Salesforce, HubSpot, Stripe, Shopify, GA4), and CDC/ELT options.
  - Modeling: Visual/no-code transforms, semantic/metrics catalog, lineage, testing, versioning.
  - Insights: Dashboards, reports, alerts, NLQ, anomaly detection, forecasting.
  - Delivery: Embedded analytics, reverse ETL to CRM/marketing tools, Slack/email alerts.
  - Governance: Row/column-level security, SSO/SCIM, roles, audit logs; SOC 2 roadmap.
- Deployment: Cloud SaaS with VPC/private deployment option for regulated customers.

Business model
- PLG + sales-assisted:
  - Free tier for small teams; paid tiers by creator seat + usage (compute/rows) or data sources.
  - Mid-market plan: SSO, governance, priority support.
  - Enterprise: VPC deployment, advanced security, premium SLAs.
- Optional professional services for onboarding/metric modeling, channel partner implementations.

Go-to-market
- Bottom-up PLG:
  - Free tier, instant connectors, sample datasets, prebuilt vertical templates.
  - Strong docs, tutorials, community, and content/SEO around “metrics layer,” “self-serve analytics,” and “operational analytics.”
- Sales-assisted:
  - Target RevOps/Finance/Data leaders; ROI-driven demos using customer data.
  - Partnerships with data agencies/SIs; co-selling with warehouse vendors.
  - Case studies highlighting speed-to-value and governed metrics consistency.

Competition and differentiation
- Competitors: Tableau, Power BI, Looker; Metabase, Mode; “assemble-your-own” modern stack (Fivetran/dbt/Snowflake + BI); embedded analytics providers.
- Differentiation (to validate which apply):
  - Integrated stack reduces time-to-value and tooling complexity.
  - Semantic/metrics layer with governance usable by both data and business teams.
  - No-code modeling and vertical templates accelerate onboarding.
  - Operational delivery (alerts, reverse ETL) closes the loop from insight to action.
  - Better TCO vs stitching multiple tools; strong security/compliance posture.

Team
- Founding team: Mix of data engineering, product, and GTM experience.
- Near-term hires: Founding full-stack engineer, data engineer, Head of Marketing/Growth, Sales AE/SDR, Solutions Engineer.
- Advisory: Security/compliance lead; partner ecosystem manager.

Traction and milestones (targets to refine)
- Year 1 targets:
  - 50–100 paying customers; $500k–$1M ARR.
  - Activation rate >40% of sign-ups reaching first dashboard/alert in 7 days.
  - NRR ≥110%; logo churn <2%/month.
  - SOC 2 Type I completed; 30+ connectors; 10 vertical templates.
- Year 2 targets:
  - $2M–$5M ARR; enterprise features (VPC, row-level security at scale); embedded analytics GA.

Financials (example framework)
- Pricing example (to validate):
  - Starter: Free up to 2 creators, limited connectors/usage.
  - Team: $49–$99 per creator/month + usage; SSO add-on.
  - Growth: $499–$1,499/month base + usage; governance, priority support.
  - Enterprise: Custom; VPC, advanced security, SLAs.
- Unit economics assumptions:
  - Gross margin 80–85% (cloud infra, support).
  - Blended CAC via PLG + sales-assisted: $2k–$8k for mid-market customers; payback <12 months.
  - LTV driven by multi-year retention and seat/usage expansion.
- 18-month plan:
  - Use funds to reach $1M–$2M ARR, SOC 2, and enterprise-readiness, setting up for a Seed/Series A.

Funding needs
- Raise: $2M–$3M seed (depending on traction), 18-month runway.
- Use of funds:
  - 40% product/engineering (connectors, metrics layer, governance, AI/NLQ).
  - 25% GTM (growth marketing, sales hires, partner ecosystem).
  - 20% security/compliance (SOC 2, SSO/SCIM, data residency/VPC).
  - 15% cloud infrastructure and support.
- Milestones to hit before next round:
  - ARR ≥$1.5M, NRR ≥110%, SOC 2 complete, 3–5 enterprise logos, partner channel contributing ≥20% of new ARR.

Risks and mitigations
- Crowded market: Focus on speed-to-value, metrics governance, and operational delivery; vertical templates.
- Data security concerns: Invest early in compliance, VPC options, granular permissions.
- Adoption friction: PLG motion, excellent onboarding, prebuilt templates, services partners.
- Integration breadth: Prioritize top 20 connectors, telemetry-driven roadmap.

Core metrics to track
- Time-to-first-insight (TTFI), weekly active teams, dashboard/alert usage, expansion seats/usage.
- Conversion from free to paid, CAC/payback, NRR/logo churn.
- Connector coverage, deployment success rate, support SLAs.

Would you like to refine this plan?
If you share details for the questions above (ICP, product scope, integrations, pricing, traction, team, and funding), I’ll update the vision/mission and tailor each section to ACME Analytics, including specific numbers, GTM tactics, and a financial model aligned with your current stage.",

    "output": "Thanks for the URL. Before I draft the YC-style business plan, I need a few tailored details to ensure the plan reflects your actual vision, product, market, and traction.

First, vision and mission
- What is your vision (long-term change you aim to create)?
- What is your mission (what you do today to achieve that vision)?

Customers and problem
- Who is your primary customer segment (e.g., utility-scale renewables owners/operators, IPPs, commercial/industrial energy managers, residential, microgrids, data centers)?
- What top 1–2 painful problems do they face that you solve (e.g., asset underperformance, downtime, fragmented data, forecasting errors, grid constraints, energy cost volatility)?
- How are these problems solved today (status quo/competing tools/services), and why is that insufficient?

Solution and product
- What exactly is your product (software platform, AI optimization engine, hardware + software, managed service)? Key features?
- What outcomes do you deliver (e.g., % increase in energy yield, % reduction in O&M cost, forecasting accuracy improvement, payback period)?
- Key integrations/data sources (SCADA, OEM sensors, EMS/BMS, market data, weather providers)? Any proprietary data?
- Any regulatory/compliance requirements you address (e.g., grid codes, ISO/RTO markets, cybersecurity)?

Market and positioning
- Target geographies and asset types (wind, solar, storage, hybrid)? Size of target market in next 3–5 years?
- Top 3 competitors or alternatives your customers compare you to. How do you outperform them?

Traction and metrics
- Current stage: pilots, paying customers, ARR/MRR, assets under management/monitoring, total MW under management, number of sites?
- Key customer logos or segments you can share.
- Core KPIs: retention/churn, average deployment time, typical ROI or payback for customers.

Business model and pricing
- Pricing model (SaaS per MW/site, tiered features, usage-based, implementation fee, services)?
- Typical contract length and sales cycle.
- Gross margin on software and services.

Go-to-market
- Primary channels (direct sales, channel partners, OEMs, EPCs, utilities)?
- Your ICP (ideal customer profile) and buyer persona (title, budget owner).
- What’s working best today for lead generation (events, referrals, content, partnerships)?

Team and capabilities
- Founders’ backgrounds and domain/technical expertise.
- Current team size and critical roles filled/missing (data science, energy trading, sales, field ops).
- Unique technical advantages (models, IP, algorithms, patents).

Moat and defensibility
- Data, models, or workflows that get better with scale (network/data effects)?
- Switching costs for customers? Key integrations that create lock-in?

Operations and risks
- Implementation requirements (on-prem vs cloud, cybersecurity posture, IT approvals).
- Key risks (regulatory, grid, vendor dependencies, data access, OEM relationships) and mitigations.

Financials and funding
- Current runway, monthly burn, and top cost drivers.
- Funding history and current raise target (amount, instrument, valuation range).
- Planned use of funds and 12–18 month milestones (product, market, team).

Roadmap
- Next 6–12 months: major product releases, integrations, certifications, markets.
- 3-year vision for product and business.

Once you share these, I’ll draft a YC-style business plan tailored to Greenbyte, including problem, solution, market, product, business model, team, financials, traction, and funding needs—then iterate with you to refine it.",

    "output": "Below is an initial, Y Combinator–style business plan draft for Nova Energia based on typical offerings of Brazilian energy companies with similar positioning. Because I may not capture every detail from your Portuguese site, I’ve noted assumptions and included targeted questions (in English) to refine the plan.

Vision
- Make clean, affordable, and transparent energy the default for Brazilian businesses.
- Empower companies to reduce costs and emissions by opening access to Brazil’s free energy market and renewables, backed by data-driven risk management.

Mission
- Provide end-to-end energy commercialization, portfolio management, and renewable procurement so customers can migrate to the free market, hedge risk, and meet sustainability goals—delivered through a technology-led, service-driven model.

Assumptions (please confirm or correct)
- Nova Energia operates as a Brazilian energy trader/retailer and advisor in the free market (ACL), helping C&I customers migrate from the regulated market (ACR) to ACL.
- Offerings include energy procurement and hedging, risk management, portfolio management (CCEE operations), long-term renewable PPAs, distributed generation (DG/“GD”) subscriptions, and environmental certificates (e.g., I-REC).
- A digital platform provides forecasting, analytics, and billing transparency for clients.
- Primary customers are mid-market and large industrial/commercial consumers; secondary customers may include generators and developers seeking offtake.
- Revenue comes from spreads (R$/MWh), management fees, consulting/origination fees, and potential SaaS subscription for digital tools.

Problem
- Energy costs and volatility are high; migrating and operating in ACL is complex (CCEE, PLD/NEWAVE/DECOMP exposure, collateral requirements).
- Many C&I buyers lack transparent pricing, reliable forecasting, ESG-aligned supply, and professional risk management.
- Generators and developers need credible offtake and structured PPAs to finance projects.

Solution
- One-stop energy commercialization and management: migration to ACL, procurement and hedging, CCEE settlement, digital monitoring, and sustainability solutions.
- Structured renewable PPAs and DG subscriptions to reduce costs and emissions.
- Data-driven risk controls and credit underwriting to protect both sides.
- Optional add-ons: I-REC/renewable certificates, demand-side efficiency, and reporting for ESG.

Why Now
- Regulatory tailwinds toward expanding ACL access (progressive liberalization and market modernization).
- Corporate decarbonization pressures and board-level ESG commitments.
- Rapid growth of DG and utility-scale renewables; new financing structures need professional offtake management.
- Technology and data availability enabling better forecasting/pricing.

Market
- Brazil electricity consumption ~650 TWh/year; ACL already a large share and expanding to mid-sized consumers.
- SAM: C&I customers eligible to migrate or already in ACL seeking better terms, risk management, and ESG solutions.
- SOM: Industries and multi-site commercial chains with meaningful load (e.g., 5–100 GWh/year per client) and appetite for renewables.
- Competitive landscape includes Comerc Energia, Delta Energia, Tradener, Safira, 2W Energia, Enel Trading, Âmbar, and regional DG providers—space remains fragmented, with differentiation possible via technology, transparency, and ESG.

Product
- Energy management: forecasting, procurement, hedging, scheduling, CCEE operations, settlement, billing.
- Renewable PPAs: structured terms (baseload/intermittent, seasonal profiles), price corridors, collars/swaps.
- Distributed Generation: solar plant subscriptions for SMEs and multi-site customers, with consolidated billing and guaranteed discounts versus ACR tariffs.
- Sustainability: I-REC and GHG reporting; renewable-only portfolios; emissions dashboards.
- Platform features: real-time consumption analytics, risk dashboards (VaR, exposure), invoice reconciliation, alerts, and scenario planning.

Business Model
- Core: Spread per MWh on contracted energy (long-term PPAs and short-term balancing).
- Fees: Migration/consulting, portfolio management, CCEE operations, origination fees for PPAs/DG.
- SaaS: Tiered subscription for analytics and reporting (optional).
- Certificates: Margin on I-REC procurement and ESG advisory.

Go-To-Market
- Direct sales to C&I accounts via industry vertical focus (food & beverage, pulp & paper, mining, retail chains, healthcare).
- Partnerships with energy consultants, banks, and equipment/DG installers.
- Content-led marketing: case studies with cost savings and emissions reductions; “ACL migration” playbooks.
- Risk-managed offers: standardized PPAs, guaranteed discounts, transparent price references.

Traction (placeholders; please supply)
- Number of clients under management and total contracted energy (GWh/TWh).
- Average contract tenor and % renewable mix.
- Churn, NPS, and savings delivered versus ACR benchmarks.
- Pipeline: MW under negotiation and signed LOIs.

Team
- Trading and risk management leadership with deep CCEE know-how.
- Origination and structured products expertise for PPAs/DG.
- Data/engineering for forecasting, optimization, and platform development.
- Operations/regulatory specialists for compliance and settlement.

Financials and Unit Economics (illustrative; please supply actuals)
- Revenue streams: spread (R$/MWh), management fees, consulting, SaaS.
- Gross margin per MWh and blended margins by product (PPAs vs DG vs operations).
- Collateral/guarantee requirements for CCEE and working capital needs.
- Credit underwriting processes and default reserves.
- 24-month projection: contracted TWh, revenue, gross margin, operating costs (trading desk, platform dev, sales), and EBITDA breakeven.

Funding Needs (illustrative)
- Raise R$ X million to:
  - Scale origination and client acquisition.
  - Build/expand the digital platform, data models, and integrations (CCEE, metering, billing).
  - Provide working capital for collateral/guarantees and manage PLD exposure.
  - Add structured products capacity (risk limits, credit insurance, diversified portfolio).

Milestones
- 12 months: 250 GWh contracted, 50+ clients, platform v1 live, 70% renewable mix, NPS > 60.
- 24 months: 1 TWh contracted, 150+ clients, platform v2, 85% renewable mix, default rate < 1%, EBITDA breakeven.
- 36 months: 3–5 TWh contracted, regional expansion, integrated certificates marketplace, AI-driven forecasting.

Key Risks and Mitigations
- Price volatility/PLD spikes: disciplined hedging, VAR limits, scenario analysis, diversified portfolio.
- Counterparty credit risk: strict underwriting, collateral, credit insurance, diversified client base.
- Regulatory changes: proactive compliance, legal advisory, flexible contract structures.
- Concentration risk in intermittent renewables: portfolio balancing, storage/Demand Response options, seasonal shaping.

Core KPIs
- Contracted energy (MWh/TWh) and pipeline MW.
- Gross margin per MWh and contribution by product.
- VAR/exposure, hedging ratio, and settlement accuracy.
- Client savings vs ACR benchmark; churn; NPS.
- % renewable supply; certificates delivered.
- Days sales outstanding; defaults; collateral utilization.

Targeted Questions (please answer in English)
1) Business scope
- Are you primarily an energy trader/retailer in ACL, a generator/developer, a DG subscription provider, or a mix?
- Do you operate your own generation assets (solar/wind/SHPP) or source from third parties via PPAs?
- Do you offer environmental certificates (I-REC) and ESG reporting?

2) Customers and traction
- Who are your core customer segments (industry verticals, average annual consumption per client)?
- Current traction: number of active clients, contracted energy (GWh/TWh), average contract term.
- What is your average % renewable supply per client?

3) Revenue model and pricing
- What is the revenue split among spread per MWh, management/consulting fees, DG subscriptions, and any SaaS components?
- Typical spread or fee ranges and margins?
- Do you charge upfront migration fees or performance-based fees?

4) Risk and credit
- How do you manage market risk (hedging policy, VAR limits, mark-to-market, stress tests)?
- Credit policy: collateral requirements for clients, use of credit insurance, default experience.

5) Operations and tech
- Are you a CCEE participant? What systems do you use for scheduling, settlement, and forecasting?
- Do you have a proprietary platform? Key features and integrations (metering, billing, SCADA)?
- Data science capabilities: forecasting load/price, optimization models.

6) Team
- Team size and key roles (trading, origination, risk, ops, engineering).
- Founders’ backgrounds and prior experience in energy/finance/tech.

7) Financials
- Last 12 months revenue and gross margin; operating costs; runway.
- Working capital needs for collateral/guarantees; typical monthly exposure.
- 24–36 month growth targets for clients and contracted energy.

8) Competition and differentiation
- Who do you consider your top competitors?
- What’s your unique value proposition (e.g., tech transparency, renewable guarantees, better pricing, sector focus)?

9) Regulatory and strategy
- Any specific regulatory licenses/permissions you hold?
- Plans for expansion (new regions, products like storage, demand response, carbon markets)?

10) Funding
- Are you raising capital now? Target amount, instrument (equity/debt), and use of funds.
- Key milestones the raise will unlock (clients, TWh, platform releases).

Once you provide these details, I’ll refine the plan with precise market sizing, unit economics, competitive positioning, and a clear funding narrative tailored to Nova Energia.",

user_provided_answers:
- revenue_model: 15% commission on each lesson booking
- team: 3 founders (CTO, CEO, COO) + 2 contractors
- challenges: Cold-start on both sides; supply quality assurance
- pricing: Tutors set their hourly rates; minimum $15/hr
- traction: 1,200 students, 300 tutors; $8k GMV last month

    "output": "Vision
- A world where every learner gets a personalized mentor.

Mission
- Make high-quality 1:1 tutoring accessible and affordable for US high school students.

What I see from your website
- TutorLane appears to be a two-sided marketplace connecting US high school students with vetted tutors for live 1:1 sessions.
- Tutors set their own hourly rates with a minimum of $15/hour; booking and payments are handled in-platform.
- Positioning emphasizes affordability, accessible matching, and quality assurance for high school subjects and test prep.

Initial questions to tighten the plan
- What is your average hourly rate today, and median rate by subject (e.g., Algebra II, AP Calculus, SAT/ACT, AP Physics)?
- What percent of your 1,200 students are “active” monthly, and what is the average lessons per active student per month?
- Current top acquisition channels: SEO, paid social, school partnerships, referrals, counselor networks? What are your current CACs by channel?
- Tutor quality ops: acceptance rate, vetting steps (credentials, background checks), and target quality metrics (CSAT/NPS thresholds, on-time rate)?
- Do you provide built-in video and lesson notes/progress reports, or integrate Zoom/Google Meet? Any parent dashboard?
- Refund/satisfaction policy for first lesson and trust & safety measures for minors (COPPA compliance, session recordings, parental consent)?
- Growth velocity: last 3 months GMV trend and seasonality (e.g., AP/SAT peaks)?
- Planned geographic focus within the US (national vs. metro-by-metro go-to-market)?

YC-style business plan (draft v1)

Problem
- US high school students need personalized support to master core subjects and prepare for AP/SAT/ACT.
- Existing options are often expensive (>$60/hour), opaque in quality, and hard to schedule. Marketplace options vary widely in tutor quality and lack transparency.
- Parents and students struggle to quickly find vetted, affordable tutors and to measure progress. Tutoring companies struggle with cold-start: balancing supply and demand while maintaining quality.

Solution
- A curated, affordable 1:1 tutoring marketplace focused exclusively on US high school students.
- Fast matching based on subject, availability, price, and quality signals; transparent tutor profiles; easy booking and payment; ongoing progress tracking.
- Quality assurance loop: robust vetting, trial sessions, continuous ratings/NPS, tutor coaching, and clear minimum performance thresholds.

Target market
- Primary: US high school students (grades 9–12) for core subjects and test prep (APs, SAT/ACT).
- TAM: US private tutoring is an ~$8–10B market; high school segment online 1:1 is an estimated $3–5B with growing online penetration post-COVID.
- Beachhead: AP STEM, Algebra/Calculus, Chemistry/Physics, SAT/ACT—time-bound, high-intent demand with predictable seasonal peaks.

Product
- Student-facing: search/match across subjects, tutor profiles (rate, experience, ratings), instant booking, payments, scheduling, messaging, optional parent oversight.
- Tutor-facing: onboarding, credential verification, calendar, pricing, payment, feedback analytics, quality coaching.
- Safety/quality: identity verification, credentials/background checks where applicable, first-lesson satisfaction policy, ongoing performance monitoring.
- Roadmap priorities:
  - AI-powered matching using availability, price, ratings, subject proficiency, and historical outcomes.
  - Progress tracking: lesson notes, goals, weekly summaries to parents; standardized skills rubrics per subject.
  - AP/SAT program flows: multi-session packages aligned to exam calendars; diagnostics to plan study paths.
  - Referral and ambassador programs; counselor portal.
  - Membership tier for families (discounted service fees, concierge matching, priority support).
  - Tutor upskilling: micro-credentials, training modules, QA dashboards.
  - Trust & safety: minor-specific safeguards, COPPA compliance, clear consent flows; option to record sessions for dispute resolution.

Business model
- 15% commission on GMV per lesson booking; tutors set rates (min $15/hour).
- Potential revenue enhancements (to test):
  - Student service fee (e.g., 5%) with transparent value (trust & safety, support, progress reporting) to lift blended take without raising tutor costs.
  - Tiered commission: 20% on first 5 lessons with a new student, then 12–15% thereafter, balancing acquisition and retention.
  - Family membership (e.g., $10–$20/month) for concierge matching, faster support, and reduced service fees.
  - Prepaid packages with mild discount to increase retention and cash flow.
  - Group micro-sessions (2–3 students) for AP review to expand affordability and margin.

Traction
- 1,200 students and 300 tutors on the platform.
- $8k GMV last month; at 15% take rate, ~$1.2k platform revenue.
- Early proof of demand across multiple subjects; clear need to improve density, matching speed, and retention.

Go-to-market
- Demand side:
  - Performance marketing: search ads against “AP [Subject] tutor,” “SAT math tutor,” “algebra tutor near me.” Target peak windows (AP season, SAT test dates).
  - SEO: content hubs for AP guides, practice problems, tutor comparison pages, and local “Best [Subject] Tutors in [City]” landing pages.
  - Ambassador program: school-by-school student reps; referral credits to both students and tutors.
  - Counselor network: relationships with guidance departments; co-branded flyers and counselor referral codes.
  - Parent channels: Facebook/Nextdoor groups; education influencers on TikTok/Instagram; UGC showcasing success stories.
- Supply side:
  - Recruit top college students, licensed teachers, and proven online tutors; highlight flexible hours and reliable earnings.
  - Partnerships with universities and teacher prep programs; targeted outreach to honor societies.
  - Quality-led onboarding: sample lesson, subject diagnostics, micro-credential badges; clear rate guidance by subject/experience.

Quality assurance
- Vetting: identity verification, credential checks, subject proficiency assessments, mock teaching demo; background checks for those working with minors.
- Performance thresholds: maintain ≥4.7 rating, ≥90% on-time rate, low cancellation rate; probation and coaching for borderline performers.
- First-lesson satisfaction guarantee: credit toward a new tutor if expectations aren’t met.
- Ongoing QA: periodic lesson reviews, parent/student NPS, issue resolution SLA; tutor coaching resources.

Unit economics (targets to validate)
- Example assumptions to test:
  - Average hourly rate: $28–$35; 1-hour sessions.
  - Average active student: 3–4 sessions/month during engagement periods.
  - Monthly revenue per active student: ~$12–$21 at 15% take.
  - CAC targets: $25–$60 via paid channels; <$20 via referrals/SEO/ambassadors.
  - Payback: within 1–2 months of activation; LTV ideally $120–$240 revenue over a 6–12 month cycle across multiple subjects/exams.
- Implication: 15% take may constrain margins; add student service fee or tiered commission to lift blended take while preserving affordability.

Competitive landscape
- Wyzant, Varsity Tutors, Preply, Skooli, TakeLessons, local tutoring centers.
- Differentiation:
  - Narrow focus on US high school subjects and exam prep with tailored QA and progress tracking.
  - Transparent pricing with affordability guardrails; faster matching; minor-specific trust & safety.
  - Data-driven outcomes: subject-specific rubrics, progress summaries for parents.

Team
- 3 founders: CEO, CTO, COO; 2 contractors.
- Near-term hires with the pre-seed:
  - Marketplace Operations Lead (trust & safety, QA, supply curation).
  - Growth Lead (performance marketing, SEO, ambassador program).
  - Full-stack Engineer (matching, payments, dashboards).
  - Part-time Subject Lead for AP/SAT curriculum and content.

Financials and milestones (12–18 months)
- Starting point: $8k monthly GMV; ~$1.2k revenue.
- Target by month 12:
  - GMV: $100k+/month; revenue at current take: $15k+/month (or $20k+ with blended service fees).
  - Active students: 3,000+; active tutors: 800+; fill rate ≥85%; time-to-first-lesson <24 hours.
  - Retention: 60% 8-week retention during exam season; average 3+ sessions per active student/month.
  - CAC: <$50 blended; payback ≤1 month; refund rate <5%.
- Month 18:
  - GMV: $200k+/month; revenue $30k–$40k/month; readiness for Seed with clear PMF in at least two verticals (AP STEM, SAT).
- Key KPIs to track:
  - Supply/demand density per subject and metro, match time, first-to-lesson conversion.
  - Tutor Quality Index (ratings, on-time, rebook rate), Student NPS, cohort retention curves.
  - CAC by channel, payback, LTV, refunds/cancellations, trust & safety incidents.

Funding needs
- Ask: $500k pre-seed to reach PMF.
- Use of funds (approximate allocation):
  - Growth experiments and paid marketing: 30%.
  - Product and engineering (matching, progress tracking, mobile-friendly UX): 35%.
  - Trust & safety and QA ops (background checks, vetting tooling, support): 20%.
  - Content/SEO and school/counselor partnerships: 10%.
  - Legal/compliance and runway buffer: 5%.
- Runway: 15–18 months targeting a burn of $25k–$35k/month.

Risks and mitigation
- Cold-start marketplace: go school-by-school and subject-by-subject; seed dense supply in AP math/science and SAT in selected metros.
- Low take rate vs. margins: test service fees and tiered commissions; push prepaid packages and memberships.
- Quality variance: invest in vetting, demo lessons, training, ongoing monitoring; remove consistently underperforming tutors quickly.
- Seasonality: lock in multi-subject progression plans (Algebra → Precalc → SAT), upsell AP packages; build content that captures evergreen demand.

Action plan next 90 days
- Pick 5–10 high schools per metro (2–3 metros) and 4 core subjects + SAT; drive local density with ambassadors and counselor outreach.
- Launch first-lesson satisfaction guarantee and standard QA thresholds; instrument NPS and rebook rates.
- Ship progress reports and simple parent dashboard; add AP/SAT package flows.
- Stand up performance marketing against high-intent keywords; build 50+ SEO pages for AP/school/city combos.
- Referral program: $20 credit both sides; tutor refer-a-tutor bonuses focused on AP/STEM.
- Pricing experiments: introduce a small student service fee and tiered commission for new relationships; measure impact on conversion and margins.

Open questions to refine the plan
- Average hourly rate and distribution by subject; current mix across core subjects vs. AP vs. SAT/ACT.
- Conversion funnel metrics: visitor → sign-up → first booking → second booking; time to first lesson.
- Current retention by cohort (weeks/months) and rebook rate after first session.
- CAC by channel and any current school partnerships; best-performing creatives/messages.
- Finalized trust & safety policies for minors (background checks scope, parental consent, session recording).
- Tutor acceptance rate and performance removal thresholds.
- Any planned geographic focus or constraints; mobile usage vs. desktop.
- Current burn/runway and hiring priorities among the suggested roles.

If you share these details, I can tighten the unit economics, set concrete growth targets per channel, and adjust the roadmap and funding plan to maximize your odds of reaching PMF within this pre-seed. Would you like me to iterate on the plan with deeper financial projections once we confirm average rates, session frequency, CAC, and retention?",

    "output": "Vision
- A world where every factory operates with a real-time water intelligence layer—minimizing waste, ensuring compliance, and optimizing production sustainably.

Mission
- Equip food and beverage manufacturers with rugged, plug-and-play water monitoring sensors and an AI-driven SaaS platform to reduce water and chemical use, prevent downtime, and meet regulatory standards across all sites.

Initial understanding from the URL and your inputs
- Aquatix appears to offer industrial water monitoring via proprietary or integrated sensors plus a cloud dashboard designed for factory environments.
- Focus: Food and beverage manufacturers in the US and Mexico.
- Business model: Hardware sale plus per-site SaaS subscription.
- Current traction: 6 pilot sites generating $12k MRR; facing long sales cycles and on-site install requirements.
- Funding goal: $1.2M for manufacturing scale-up and UL certifications.

Targeted questions to complete the plan
1) Product and parameters
- Which parameters do you measure today (e.g., flow, pressure, pH, turbidity, conductivity, temperature, ORP, chlorine, TOC/BOD/COD, metals)?
- Primary use cases: process water, CIP optimization, boilers/cooling towers, wastewater effluent, leak detection?

2) Hardware
- Are sensors proprietary or integrated from OEMs? Typical hardware per site (number of sensors, gateways)?

- Certifications needed: UL standard (e.g., UL 61010), FCC/CE/RoHS, NSF/ANSI 61, NOM (Mexico)?

3) Software
- Key features: anomaly detection, CIP cycle analytics, compliance reporting, multi-site benchmarking, alerts, mobile app?

4) Pricing and unit economics

5) Customers and GTM
- Which subsegments are strongest (breweries, dairy, meat/poultry, beverages bottling, sugar/confectionery)?
- Decision-makers: EHS managers, plant managers, process engineers, corporate sustainability leads?
- Current pipeline size and stage; channel partners or system integrators you work with or target.

6) Traction and outcomes

7) Team and ops
